issues.title: Note from Mark Andrews on the list re: avoiding PMTUD
issues.author: ichdasich
issues.body:
For IPv6 servers should use mechanisms to avoid having to do PMTUD.

Set the MSS to the IPv6 network MTU.  This really helps when there are asymmetric
routing.

Set IPV6_USE_MINMTU to 1 on UDP sockets.  Again this helps when there are
asymmetric routing.

Both of these also help when ICMPv6 is being blocked by operators that don’t
understand IPv6.

comments.author: vixie
comments.body:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9715/

Set IPV6_USE_MINMTU to 1 on UDP sockets. Again this helps when there are

Both of these also help when ICMPv6 is being blocked by operators that don’t
understand IPv6.

—

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body:
I so far just verbatim put the mail from the list in here to keep track of the task. I agree with your point, though.

Still, the question coming up means that the text in the draft needs some wording (and ref to 9715) to make sure it does not come up.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: Ok, closing this, as I assume that the added references to 9715 and additional text on PMTU issues addresses this.

issues.title: Minor nit: weird logic conflict with definitions
issues.author: tojens-ietf
issues.body:
The definition of dual stack is currently being both an IPv4 resolver and an IPv6 resolver, which is reasonable, but the defitions of each is: 

> It does not imply anything about what DNS data is served, but requires DNS queries to be received and answered over IPvX.

A dual stack resolver can't actually require receiving and answering over both protocols (very nit, but still). Suggest changing definitions either so that "only" is mapped to the existing text and dual stack defined separately, or just change the IPvX definitions to:

> It does not imply anything about what DNS data is served, but receives and answers queries over IPvX.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: Addressed by c3df4fa44282f9575bdb2f38a6a30ce00eefd590

issues.title: Comment Erik Nguyen: Discuss resolver number limitation (3 for libc)
issues.author: ichdasich
issues.body:
Erik brought up that many implementations can only deal with a limited set of configured resolvers.

He argues that the document should provide some note on this issue, without being prescriptive to implementations, and considers making a text-suggestion.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: Technically, should be resolved.

issues.title: Comment Jen Linkova: Clarify terminologyt (mapped) and link to corresponding v6ops document in sec-con
issues.author: ichdasich
issues.body: Jen noted that the terminology in the draft needs to be clarified around derived v6 addresses (_not_ mapped); Furthermore, she noted that ongoing synthesizing implies having more than nothing in the security considerations. To fix that, a recently published document from v6ops discussing these issues should simply be referenced.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: removed mapped wording

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: added security considerations, referencing 9872.

issues.title: Stefan Ubbink: editorial comments on ML
issues.author: ichdasich
issues.body:
# 3.1.  Misconfigurations Causing IP Version Related Name Space Fragmentation
Maybe the sentence for 'No A/AAAA record for in-domain NS' can be cut into smaller sentences to improve readability.

# 4.2. Guidelines for DNS Resolvers
The first sentence starts with 'Every recursive DNS resolver...' and in 4.3 there is also a reference to 'recursive DNS resolvers'. So I think the title of the section should be 'Guidelines for Recursive DNS Resolvers'.

Why does the first mention of PREF64 in the second paragraph have RFC6164 as reference, when the second PREF64 has RFC8781 as reference (which is the same as in section 3.2)?

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body:
Ok, took a look:
1. I do not really see an easy way to make the sentence shorter.
2. Added Recursive to the section title
3. The second ref is for PREF64 discovery, while the first one pertains to the concept of a pref64.

pulls.title: change my name to be readable
pulls.author: momoka0122y

pulls.title: Remove DNS synthesis recommendation per Mark Andrews objection
pulls.author: momoka0122y
pulls.body:
## Summary

  This PR addresses feedback from mailing list discussions by removing DNS-level address synthesis and strengthening guidance for native IPv6 preference.

  ## Background

  Mark Andrews strongly objected to DNS-level address synthesis in his mailing list response:
  https://www.mail-archive.com/dnsop@ietf.org/msg31222.html

  His key argument: DNS is an application layer protocol that deals with IP address literals and should not perform network layer address transformations. Address
   synthesis should be handled at the OS/kernel level via CLAT mechanisms (RFC 6877).

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: This PR would revert changes (`<bcp14>MAY</bcp14>`) already made to address the comment without preventing the behavior, see `5f8ed59d-e3ac-4415-9f62-e77c418c0420@gmail.com`

pulls.title: Strengthen PMTUD guidance based on RFC 9715
pulls.author: momoka0122y
pulls.body:
## Summary

This PR strengthens the PMTUD (Path MTU Discovery) guidance in the draft based on RFC 9715 and mailing list discussions.

## Changes

1. **For UDP**: Changed from `MAY` to `SHOULD NOT` rely on PMTUD
   - RFC 9715 explicitly states PMTUD for DNS/UDP is "harmful and dangerous"

2. **For TCP**: Changed from `MAY` to `SHOULD` use IPV6_USE_MIN_MTU=1
   - Provides stronger guidance to avoid PMTUD issues

## Background

- Recent discussions from December 2024 about PMTUD being harmful
- Mark Andrews and others confirmed that PMTUD for DNS/UDP should be avoided

RFC 9715 Section 3.1 and Appendix C confirm that PMTUD for DNS/UDP is considered harmful, with all major DNS implementations explicitly disabling it using IP_PMTUDISC_OMIT.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: This PR would revert changes made to the text based on `5f8ed59d-e3ac-4415-9f62-e77c418c0420@gmail.com` and before.

pulls.title: Fix XML syntax error in author element
pulls.author: momoka0122y
pulls.body:
## Summary

This PR fixes a simple XML syntax error in the author element that was causing XML parsing failures.

## Change

The author element on line 15 was missing a closing angle bracket (`>`).

pulls.title: Add examples for missing IPv6 GLUE and zone validation
pulls.author: ramonsoarezcavalcante
pulls.body:
This PR adds two examples to improve operator understanding:

1. Section 3.1.1 (Misconfigurations):   A `dig` example showing how missing IPv6 GLUE in a parent zone breaks resolution for IPv6-only resolvers.

2. Section 4.1 (Authoritative DNS Configuration):   A validation checklist and `dig` command for testing IPv6-only resolution.

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: Before I review this PR, could you please comment whether any AI tools were used when creating its contents? This is important in the context of the note-well.

comments.author: ramonsoarezcavalcante
comments.body:
I would like to note that I relied on artificial intelligence (specifically Grok, from xAI) in the initial phase of developing the XML examples and organizing the proposed changes. However, i thoroughly reviewed, tested, and refined all of the material manually. This ensured that it was fully in line with the purposes of the draft. For example, I validated the XML using the author-tools.ietf.org tool, which resulted in zero errors. The AI did not create any normative text or the main ideas, these derive from my knowledge of DNS best practices, based on the RFCs.

The inclusions in this PR were directly inspired by draft-ietf-dnsop-glue-is-not-optional (accessible at: https://github.com/ietf-wg-dnsop/draft-ietf-dnsop-glue-is-not-optional/blob/main/draft-ietf-dnsop-glue-is-not-optional.md).

comments.author: ichdasich
comments.body: I will not expend time and energy to engage with AI generated content.

pulls.title: Added comment on max. of three resolvers.
pulls.author: ichdasich
pulls.body: During dnsop at 124, there was a comment that some implementations only support up to three NS (libc most prominently). It was recommended to at least note this issue in the document. This PR implements that.
